overview: GitHub Issues now supports pinning a comment to the top of an issue and includes a nudge to discourage low-quality comments like '+1' or 'same here', encouraging reactions and subscriptions instead.

detailed_explanation.title: Pinned comments
bullets: Users can now pin a comment to the top of an issue via the comment '...' menu.
Pinned comments surface key updates, decisions, or next steps for anyone viewing the issue.
Helps readers quickly understand what matters most without scrolling through the entire thread.

detailed_explanation.title: Low-quality comment nudge
bullets: A nudge encourages people to react or subscribe instead of leaving comments like '+1' or 'same here'.
Reduces noise, clutter, and unnecessary notifications on issues.
Still provides an easy way to show support and stay updated through reactions.

key_changes: Comment pinning is now available on GitHub Issues via the '...' menu.
A UI nudge discourages low-quality comments and suggests using reactions instead.
impact: Issue maintainers can pin important comments to improve discoverability of key decisions and updates.
All GitHub users will see the nudge when attempting to leave low-signal comments on issues.
Teams managing high-traffic issues benefit from reduced notification noise.
caveats: The article does not specify how many comments can be pinned per issue.
The article does not state whether pinning is available for pull request comments as well.
The nudge behavior (exact trigger, dismissibility) is not described in detail.
insights: Comment pinning addresses a long-standing request for surfacing decisions in long issue threads.
The low-quality comment nudge is a soft intervention rather than a hard block, preserving user freedom while guiding behavior.
Together, these features improve the signal-to-noise ratio in issue discussions, which is especially valuable for popular open-source projects.
